Option D. Calcaneal fracture with increased Gissane angle: Some displaced calcaneal fractures may show an increased Gissane angle, but the principal diagnostic marker is a reduced Bohler angle, making this option less accurate for the case described

questions.text: A 15-year-old male with pain and swelling gradually increasing over 4 months at the upper end of tibia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brodie abscess

 

Brodie abscess is a form of subacute or chronic osteomyelitis, presenting with gradually increasing pain and swelling without systemic symptoms—a classic pattern in adolescents with tibial metaphyseal lesions. Radiographs typically show a well-defined lytic lesion surrounded by reactive sclerosis, and it most often affects the upper tibial metaphysis. The insidious course makes it distinct from tumors or acute infections, and inflammatory markers are often normal, fitting the described clinical scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoclastoma: Also known as giant cell tumor, typically occurs after skeletal maturity, often around 20–40 years of age, and presents with rapidly progressive pain and swelling; it rarely has such a slow course in adolescents.

 

Option B. Ewing sarcoma: Usually presents with rapid onset of pain, fever, swelling, and possible systemic signs; radiographs show permeative bone destruction and significant periosteal reaction. It is more aggressive than Brodie abscess and often involves the diaphysis, not metaphysis.

 

Option D. Osteosarcoma: Common in adolescents, typically presents with progressive swelling and pain, but radiographically shows aggressive bone formation, a "sunburst" pattern, and soft tissue extension, which is not consistent with a well-circumscribed abscess lesion

questions.text: 6-year-old boy is brought to the OPD for evaluation of back pain. The pain has been constant for the last 2 weeks and keeps the patient from playing with his friends. He wakes up several times nightly to void and has had episodes of incontinence as the leg pain prevents him from walking to the bathroom. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Langerhans cell histiocytosis 

 

Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) in children can present with persistent back pain, restricted mobility, and vertebral lesions causing nocturnal symptoms and urinary dysfunction. Vertebral involvement may result in nerve root or spinal cord compression, explaining both the pain and episodes of incontinence described. LCH commonly affects flat bones, including the vertebrae, and produces lytic bone lesions; children present with bone pain, systemic complaints, and sometimes features of diabetes insipidus or neurological compromise. The constellation of long-standing back pain, sleep disturbance, and neurologic/urinary signs strongly favors LCH over more aggressive or syndromic entities in this pediatric age group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewing-sarcoma: More commonly presents with fever, markedly elevated inflammatory markers, and aggressive soft tissue masses; pain is rapid in onset and usually associated with systemic signs. It is rare in children this young and classically affects diaphyseal bone.

 

 

Option C. Mazzabraud-syndrome: Features fibrous dysplasia and intramuscular myxomas, primarily presenting as slow-growing soft-tissue lumps and bony deformity rather than acute back pain or urinary symptoms; it is very rare in children.

 

Option D. Mccune-Albright.syndrome: Triad of polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, café-au-lait spots, and endocrine abnormalities, most notably precocious puberty and hormonal excess. Such a syndrome rarely presents with isolated back pain and bladder dysfunction as primary symptoms

questions.text: 6-year-old girl is brought to the clinic for evaluation of knee pain. The patient first had soreness in her right knee 4 days ago, after her first gymnastics class. Her mother gave her PCM and massaged her knee, but this did not help. The patient also developed a limp over the past 2 days. She has no chronic medical conditions and does not take daily medications. Height is at the 50th percentile and weight is at the 90th percentile. Temperature is 37.9 °C (100.2 °F). When walking, she limits weight-bearing on her right side. When supine, the right hip is held flexed with the knee pointed laterally. There is limited internal rotation and extension of the right hip. The right knee has full range of motion and there is no tenderness on palpation around the knee. Laboratory evaluation shows leukocyte count of 11,500/mm and C-reactive protein of 8 mg/L (normal: <10). Ultrasound of the hips shows small, bilateral effusions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transient synovitis

 

Transient synovitis is the most common cause of acute hip pain and limp in children aged 3–8 years, frequently presenting after minor trauma or viral illness. Key features include sudden onset hip pain, limp, mild fever, limited hip motion (especially internal rotation and extension), normal or slightly elevated inflammatory markers, and ultrasound showing small bilateral hip effusions. The hip is usually held flexed and externally rotated to relieve pain, and the child remains well-appearing overall, with rapid improvement expected with supportive management. These findings all fit the description in this case, distinguishing transient synovitis from more serious or chronic causes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Juvenile idiopathic arthritis: Usually affects multiple joints, with persistent pain, swelling, and thickened synovium on imaging; systemic features or chronicity are common, and effusion is often more pronounced and persistent. Fever and systemic unwell feeling tend to be more marked than in transient synovitis.

 

Option B. Perthes disease: Presents with chronic limp, reduced range of motion, and radiographic evidence of avascular necrosis of the femoral head, but not acute limp with effusion nor bilateral involvement on ultrasound in an otherwise well child.

 

 

Option C. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis: Seen most often in obese, preteen or teenage boys, with chronic limp and characteristic changes on radiographs (epiphyseal slip); rarely acute, and peak age is higher than in this scenario.

questions.text: All of the following are susceptible to AVN except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neck of talus

 

Avascular necrosis (AVN) commonly occurs in bones or bone segments with tenuous blood supply, such as the proximal pole of the scaphoid, the head of the femur, and the head of the humerus. These regions are at increased risk especially following fractures disrupting their vascularity. In contrast, it is not the neck but the body of the talus that is most susceptible to AVN after neck fractures; the neck itself, if isolated, is rarely the site of AVN—the risk comes from disruption of blood flow to the body of talus when the neck is fractured.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proximal pole of scaphoid: Highly prone to AVN after fracture because of retrograde blood supply and frequent disruption from injury, leading to increased risk of nonunion and collapse.

 

Option C. Head of femur: Classic site for AVN, with high occurrence after femoral neck fractures due to interruption of the retinacular vessels.

 

Option D. Head of humerus: The humeral head can undergo AVN following fractures, especially those involving anatomical neck or with dislocation

questions.text: 10-year-old girl with Down syndrome is brought to the clinic due to behavioural changes. Over the past month, she has stopped running, tripped frequently while walking, and accidentally knocked toys over more often than normal. The patient was toilet-trained at age 4, but recently she began having frequent urinary accidents while playing and has started wearing a diaper again. Physical examination shows an ataxic gait. Bilateral ankle deep tendon reflexes are hyperreflexic. When the soles of the feet are firmly stroked the big toes move upward and the other toes fan out. Urinalysis is normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atlantoaxial instability

 

Atlantoaxial instability is a well-recognized complication in patients with Down syndrome due to ligamentous laxity and osseous anomalies. It may present with behavioral changes, gait ataxia, regression in motor and bladder function, and upper motor neuron signs (such as hyperreflexia and Babinski response), as seen in this child. Early recognition is vital, as progression may lead to irreversible cord compression, but timely intervention can significantly improve outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early onset Alzheimer-disease: While individuals with Down syndrome are at higher risk for early-onset Alzheimer’s, the described symptoms of acute regression, ataxia, and incontinence with upper motor neuron signs are more suggestive of spinal cord compression.

 

Option C. Hypothyroidism: May cause hypotonia and mental slowdown, but would not cause ataxia, hyperreflexia, or pathological plantar responses.

 

Option D. Spinal cord infarction: Rare in children, and would typically result in more abrupt and severe symptom onset, often with focal neurological findings, not gradual regression with intermittent symptoms as in this scenario

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of a mass at her right wrist. The patient first noticed swelling in her wrist a few months ago after spending a week knitting blankets for her family.  Medical conditions include hyperlipidemia and rheumatoid arthritis.  The mass is firm, mobile, and nontender to palpation, and it transilluminates on penlight examination. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ganglion cyst

 

Ganglion cysts are the most common cause of a non-tender, firm, mobile swelling over the wrist, particularly following repeated hand movements or overuse. These cysts are fluid-filled, arising from tendon sheaths or joint capsules, and frequently transilluminate due to their clear gelatinous content. They are usually painless, may fluctuate in size, and are most often seen on the dorsal or volar aspect of the wrist, just as described in this patient with a history of knitting and risk factors including rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidermoid-cyst: These are usually firm, non-transilluminant, slow-growing, and generally occur on the palmar surface of the hand or fingers rather than the wrist. They do not typically exhibit the clear, jelly-like content seen with ganglion cysts.

 

 

Option C. Lipoma: Lipomas are soft, pliable, subcutaneous tumors that do not transilluminate, and are much less likely to develop over the wrist than ganglion cysts.

 

 

Option D. Rheumatoid-nodule: These are firm, non-transilluminant, usually arise in patients with severe rheumatoid arthritis, and are often attached to periarticular structures or tendons, not mobile, and typically slightly tender. They rarely transilluminate and are less likely to be fluid-filled

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to worsening right lower abdominal pain that radiates to the right groin area. Two weeks ago, he was treated for furunculosis of the right thigh. The patient has a history of type 1 diabetes mellites and takes insulin. Abdominal examination shows tenderness on deep palpation in the right lower quadrant without rebound or guarding. No masses are palpated. Bowel sounds are present. Extension of the right hip increases pain, and flexion decreases pain. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psoas abscess

 

Psoas abscess often arises from hematogenous spread or contiguous infection (eg, skin furunculosis, vertebral TB, Crohn’s).

 

  • Classic findings: pain in RLQ or flank, radiation to groin, positive psoas sign (pain with extension, relief with flexion).
  • Diabetes is a risk factor for deep-seated infections.

 

The image below shows Psoas abscess on left side.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute-appendicitis: Presents with RLQ pain, fever, anorexia, rebound tenderness; not typically relieved by hip flexion.

 

Option C. Small bowel-obstruction: Colicky pain, vomiting, distension, absent bowel movements; exam shows hyperactive bowel sounds initially.

 

Option D. Acute-pancreatitis: Epigastric pain radiating to back, nausea, vomiting; not localized to RLQ or affected by hip movement.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to left wrist pain after a fall. The patient was walking in his house when he tripped over a rug and landed on his outstretched hand. Medical history is notable for celiac disease, hypertension, and hypothyroidism for which he takes appropriate daily medications. X-ray of the left wrist is shown below. Which of the following is the most significant risk factor for bone fracture in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Celiac disease

 

Celiac disease is the most significant risk factor for bone fracture in this scenario because it causes chronic malabsorption of calcium and vitamin D, leading to secondary osteoporosis and increased risk of low-trauma fractures, especially at sites such as the distal radius. Numerous studies confirm that individuals with celiac disease have up to two times higher fracture risk, even before diagnosis, due to defective bone mineralization and inflammation. Prompt identification and management of celiac disease can decrease the risk but does not fully mitigate it if diagnosis is delayed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age: While increasing age is a general risk factor for osteoporotic fractures, the fracture incidence rises dramatically in those over age 65–70; this patient is 45 years old, making age less contributory in this context.

 

Option C. Hypertension: Hypertension alone is not a well-established independent risk factor for bone fragility fractures; its main impact is via associated comorbidities, not direct bone metabolism effects.

 

Option D. Hypothyroidism: Untreated or severe hypothyroidism can cause bone health changes, but it is typically associated with low turnover and reduced bone formation, not high bone fragility; treated hypothyroidism, as in this patient, does not significantly increase fracture risk.

questions.text: 61-year-old man comes to the OPD due to chronic left knee pain. The pain is worse when he first gets out of bed in the morning and is associated with mild stiffness.  On examination, the left knee has a small effusion and mild pain over the medial and lateral joint lines. There is no clicking or locking of the knee, but crepitus is present with range of motion. The patient is able to bear weight without pain and the joint is stable to varus and valgus stress. X-ray of the knee is shown in the image below: Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient's knee pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Quadriceps strengthening exercises

 

  • The patient is a 61-year-old man with chronic knee pain, stiffness, crepitus, and small effusion, consistent with osteoarthritis.
  • X-ray shows joint space narrowing and osteophytes, typical of OA.
  • Initial management of mild-to-moderate OA includes non-pharmacologic measures: quadriceps strengthening exercises, weight loss, and activity modification.
  • NSAIDs or intra-articular corticosteroid injections are considered when conservative therapy fails.
  • Knee replacement is reserved for severe, disabling OA not relieved by other measures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methotrexate: Used in rheumatoid arthritis, not OA.

 

Option B. Corticosteroid injection of the knee: Provides short-term relief in moderate to severe OA with significant symptoms, not the first-line step.

 

Option C. Knee replacement surgery: Reserved for advanced OA with severe pain and functional limitation.

questions.text: 26-year-old man with a history of seizure disorder and medication nonadherence is hospitalized after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. A witness reports that the patient lost consciousness and fell to his right side; the seizure lasted about 2 minutes. Evaluation in the emergency department reveals a low serum level of his prescribed antiepileptic drug. levetiracetam, and a displaced right femur fracture. Levetiracetam is restarted and the patient undergoes intramedullary nailing of the fracture with no intraoperative complications. The next day the patient is noted to be confused. Temperature is 37.2 °C (99 °F), blood pressure is 142/86 mm Hg, pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 28/min. Oxygen saturation is 90% while breathing room air. On physical examination, the patient is disoriented but has no focal weakness or sensory loss. There are no skin rashes or hematoma at the surgical site. CT pulmonary angiography shows bilateral scattered ground-glass opacities but no flling defects within the pulmonary vasculature. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fat embolism

 

  • This patient developed confusion + tachypnea + hypoxemia within 24–72 hours after a long bone fracture (femur).
  • CT chest shows bilateral ground-glass opacities without embolic filling defects, which is classic for fat embolism syndrome (FES) rather than pulmonary embolism.
  • The triad of respiratory distress, neurological symptoms, and petechial rash defines FES (rash may appear later or be absent).
  • Risk is highest after intramedullary nailing of long bones due to marrow fat release into circulation.

 

Gerd’s Criteria of Fat Embolism

questions.text: A 60 year old female underwent hip repalcement. After 1 year she developed fever and pain in the joint. Radiograph revealed looseding of prosthesis. The implant had to be removed. The histological image of the tissue adjoining the implant is show below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metallosis

 

  • The patient developed loosening of hip prosthesis with pain & fever after 1 year, suggesting implant-related complication.
  • Histology shows black pigment-laden macrophages in the peri-implant tissue, which is characteristic of metallosis.
  • Metallosis occurs due to wear and corrosion of metal prostheses, releasing metallic debris.
  • This causes a chronic inflammatory response with macrophage infiltration.
  • It leads to aseptic loosening of the implant without evidence of infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanoma: Would show atypical melanocytes with nuclear pleomorphism, mitotic activity, and melanin pigment, not seen here.

 

Option C. Ochronosis: Seen in alkaptonuria, with bluish-black connective tissue pigmentation due to homogentisic acid, not prosthesis-related.

 

Option D. Rosai-Dorfman syndrome: A histiocytic proliferative disorder with emperipolesis (engulfment of lymphocytes by histiocytes), not black metallic deposits.

questions.text: The following pelvic X-ray was seen in a patient. All the following signs will be present except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gaenslen sign

 

  • In DDH, the femoral head is displaced from the acetabulum.
  • Ortolani sign → palpable "clunk" felt when dislocated hip is reduced by abduction.
  • Barlow sign → dislocation of a reducible hip by gentle adduction with posterior force.
  • Narath sign → absent femoral artery pulsation due to posterior displacement of femoral head.
  • Gaenslen sign → is a provocative test for sacroiliitis, not DDH.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is evaluated for early-onset puberty and multiple bone lesions. On examination, she has café-au-lait spots as shown below. Hormonal tests confirm hyperfunction of multiple endocrine glands. What is the underlying genetic mutation in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) GNAS gene mutation

 

  • The child has café-au-lait spots with irregular borders ("coast of Maine" appearance).
  • Associated with precocious puberty, fibrous dysplasia of bone, and endocrine hyperfunction (eg, hyperthyroidism, Cushing’s, acromegaly).
  • The underlying defect is a somatic activating mutation of the GNAS gene, leading to constitutive activation of G-protein signaling and excess hormone production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NF1 gene: Neurofibromatosis type 1; café-au-lait spots but with smooth ("coast of California") borders, neurofibromas, optic gliomas.

 

Option B. GNAQ gene mutation: Sturge–Weber syndrome; port-wine stain, leptomeningeal angiomas, seizures.

 

Option D. FGFR3: Achondroplasia; causes abnormal cartilage growth → short stature, macrocephaly.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to the physician because of episodic tingling and numbness in his right hand for the past 3 weeks. He says that he cannot hold a pen very well and that this is affecting his handwriting. Sensation to light touch is decreased over the right little finger and the medial palmar surface of the right hand. Radiologic evaluation in this patient is most likely to show a fracture in which of the following bones?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) G

 

The patient presents with symptoms of ulnar nerve compression: tingling and numbness in the little finger and medial palm, with weakening grip and impaired fine hand movements. The loss of sensation in the ulnar distribution suggests injury or compression of the ulnar nerve at the wrist.

 

On the labeled hand X-ray, G points to the hook of hamate. Fracture of the hook of hamate can damage the ulnar nerve (specifically its deep branch) within Guyon's canal, resulting in the sensory and motor symptoms described. This is a classic cause of ulnar nerve dysfunction in the hand, as the nerve curves around the hook of hamate.

 

  •  (D=Scaphoid) fracture affects the anatomical snuffbox and would not produce ulnar nerve symptoms.
  •  (E=Lunate)  injuries would usually compress the median nerve (carpal tunnel syndrome).
  •  (A=Capitate)  is typically not associated with ulnar nerve symptoms.

 

Only G (hook of hamate), when fractured, is likely to cause isolated ulnar sensory and motor symptoms as described

 

F=Pisiform/Triquetrum

C=Trapezium

B=Trapezoid

questions.text: A previously healthy 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his mother because of persistent crying and refusal to move his right arm. The episode began 30 minutes ago after the mother lifted him up by the arms. He appears distressed and is inconsolable. On examination, his right arm is held close to his body in a flexed and pronated position. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Radial head subluxation

 

This presentation is classic for radial head subluxation (nursemaid’s elbow):

 

  • Age group: Most common in children 1–4 years.
  • Mechanism: Sudden longitudinal traction on the arm (e.g., lifting, pulling, swinging by the hands).
  • Clinical finding: Child holds the arm in slight flexion and pronation, refuses to use it, and is very irritable.
  • X-ray: Usually normal (clinical diagnosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proximal ulnar fracture: Would present with swelling, deformity, and tenderness; not just refusal to move.

 

 

Option B. Anterior shoulder dislocation: Rare in toddlers; arm would be abducted and externally rotated, not flexed/pronated.

 

 

Option C. Supracondylar fracture of the humerus: Common after fall on outstretched hand; presents with swelling, pain, and risk of neurovascular compromise.

questions.text: The following condition develops due to which vessel?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medial circumflex femoral artery

 

Avascular necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head typically develops after disruption of its main blood supply, which is almost entirely provided by the medial circumflex femoral artery in adults. This vessel gives rise to the posterior retinacular arteries that run along the femoral neck and supply the head; injury, especially after femoral neck fractures or hip dislocation, can easily compromise flow and cause AVN. The other arteries (especially the artery of the ligamentum teres from the obturator artery) provide only a minor supply in adults, so interruption of the medial circumflex femoral artery is the critical event leading to AVN in these settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral circumflex femoral artery: Primarily supplies the lateral thigh muscles and the anterior capsule of the hip, with only minor contribution to the femoral head. Injury to this vessel does not commonly result in AVN.

 

Option C. Obturator artery: Contributes minimally in adults via the artery of the ligamentum teres; its role in femoral head perfusion is insignificant after early childhood.

 

Option D. Profunda femoris artery: Mainly a parent vessel for the circumflex arteries, it does not directly supply the femoral head and is not relevant for AVN risk unless a branch is involved.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female complains of soft, fluctuating swelling in front of the knee. She reports discomfort and difficulty while moving her knee. MRI is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Housemaid's knee

 

Housemaid's knee is the lay term for prepatellar bursitis, which presents as a soft, fluctuant swelling directly anterior to the patella—the clinical and imaging features described in this scenario. The MRI would show fluid collection in the prepatellar bursa, situated immediately in front of the patella, consistent with prepatellar bursitis. Patients with this condition often have discomfort with knee movement and may have a history of prolonged kneeling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cleryman’s knee: This is infrapatellar bursitis, which produces swelling below the patella (not directly over it), at the level of the tibial tuberosity.

 

Option C. Gout: out can affect bursae but typically demonstrates tophi or urate crystal deposits, often with erythema, redness, and sometimes skin breakdown; the described features and swelling location are less characteristic.

 

Option D. Pes anserinus bursitis: Presents as swelling and tenderness on the medial side of the knee, well below the patella and not in its anterior aspect

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with wrist pain after a fall on an outstretched hand. The X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Volar Barton’s fracture

 

A Volar Barton's fracture is an intra-articular fracture of the distal radius involving the volar (palmar) rim and is associated with dislocation or subluxation of the radiocarpal joint towards the volar side. The X-ray in question shows a fracture of the distal radius with the carpal bones displaced volarly along with a fragment of the volar rim, which fits this classic description. The hallmark is an intra-articular fracture with volar subluxation of the carpus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colles' fracture: A Colles' fracture is an extra-articular distal radius fracture with dorsal displacement and angulation, not volar.

 

Option B. Smith’s fracture: A Smith’s fracture is an extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with volar (palmar) displacement but does not involve the articular surface or subluxation of the carpus.

 

Option D. Scaphoid fracture: A scaphoid fracture specifically involves one of the carpal bones, not the distal radius, and would not show the radiocarpal displacement described

questions.text: A 19-year-old male patient comes to the clinic for follow-up 3 weeks after a traumatic fracture in his right thigh. On examination, he was found to have a hard palpable mass near the fracture site. X-ray of the area shows the findings below. A histological section shows central fibrous tissue and mature bone at the periphery. Which of the following is true about this patient's diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myositis ossificans

 

The clinical history, X-ray findings, and histology all support this diagnosis.

 

X-ray and Histology Features

 

  • Myositis ossificans typically shows peripheral bone or calcification with a relatively lucent (less dense) center on radiographs.
  • Histologically, it is characterized by mature bone at the periphery and central immature fibrous tissue (“zone phenomenon”), which distinguishes it from parosteal osteosarcoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parosteal osteosarcoma: Parosteal osteosarcoma shows central, dense mineralization often fused with bone, which is not seen in this case.

 

 

Option C. Osteochondroma: Osteochondroma is a bone-cartilage growth usually attached to bone and has a different appearance and histology.

 

 

Option D. AV fistula: AV fistula is a vascular abnormality with no ossification or zonal histology

choices.text: No loss of nerve sheath continuity in Neurapraxia and axonotmesis
Wallerian degeneration is not seen in neurapraxia
Surgical intervention is always needed in neurotmesis
Nerve regrowth happens at 3mm per day

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about Seddon classification of nerve injuries:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nerve regrowth happens at 3mm per day

 

Actual regrowth rate is about 1–3 mm per day (average 1 mm/day).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No loss of nerve sheath continuity in neurapraxia and axonotmesis:  Correct.

 

  • In neurapraxia → conduction block, myelin damage only.
  • In axonotmesis → axon damage with intact endoneurial sheath.

 

Option B. Wallerian degeneration is not seen in neurapraxia: Correct. Only conduction block occurs, so no distal Wallerian degeneration.

 

Option C. Surgical intervention is always needed in neurotmesis: Correct. In neurotmesis, both axon and supporting sheath are completely disrupted, requiring repair.
